title: Ewer, Globular Ewer, 18th century
medium: Zinc and copper alloy; cast, engraved, inlaid with silver (bidri ware)
provenance: MMA 19.135.12, Robert W. and Lockwood De Forest, New York (until 1919)
dimensions: Max. H. (with cover) 10 5/8 in. (27.0 cm high) W. 12 in. (30.5 cm) Max. Diam. 6 9/16 in. (16.6 cm)
creditline: Lent by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, John Stewart Kennedy Fund, 1915 (15.95.12)
description: A bulbous circular section with cylindrical neck , domed lid, the angular spout extending from the base of container at a 45 degree angle, the snake-like handle at 90 degree angle extending from the hinged list to the base of the container, all on circular pedestal foot
gallery_text: De Forest was passionate about collecting and documenting traditional Indian crafts. During his travels he acquired this bidri ware pitcher with an accompanying wash basin as an example of this technique, which involves inlaying mixed metals with silver.
label_text: De Forest was passionate about collecting and documenting traditional Indian crafts. During his travels he acquired this bidri ware pitcher with an accompanying wash basin as an example of this technique, which involves inlaying mixed metals with silver.

tombstone.epitaph:
Ewer, Globular Ewer, 18th century. Zinc and copper alloy; cast, engraved, inlaid with silver (bidri ware). 
Lent by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, John Stewart Kennedy Fund, 1915 (15.95.12). 3.2012.2.
